snippet: The exchange, the world’s largest for stocks, says an “internal technical issue” prompted a shutdown of trading for nearly four hours.
abstract: Computer systems at New York Stock Exchange go down for almost four hours, halting all trading, only to go back online just before closing bell; disruption rattles investors and benchmark Standard & Poor's index ends day down 1.7 percent; halt in trading underscores degree to which computer technology has revolutionized trading and how automated systems that take care of jobs people once handled can sometimes be fragile.

byline.contributor: Matthew Goldstein and Julie Hirschfeld Davis contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The exchange, the world’s largest for stocks, says an “internal technical issue” prompted a shutdown of trading for nearly four hours.

headline.main: The Stock Market Bell Rings, Computers Fail, Wall Street Cringes
